Situation1: Communicate openly to resolve conflicts or misunderstandings.
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: Police have just begun to unexpectedly block the exits of the protest area, and you must immediately help coordinate a safe response.
Story: My phone buzzed with frantic messages as I stood at the edge of the protest, megaphone in hand. The police had started blocking the exits, and panic was spreading through the crowd. As an activist, I was expected to stay calm, organize everyone, and ensure a peaceful, safe response. But just then, I saw my younger brother in the crowd, his face pale with fear. He’d come to support me, but now he was caught in the chaos. He looked at me, eyes pleading for reassurance. As his brother, I knew I needed to talk to him, to help him understand what was happening, to resolve the fear and confusion between us. But the crowd was swelling, and my fellow organizers were calling for my help. I felt torn—my responsibility to the movement demanded my full attention, but my brother needed me, too. My heart pounded as I tried to decide which role to answer first, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
